questions.text: Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values: pH- 7.2 and pCO2 – 80 mm Hg? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

As pH = 7.2 of the patient’s blood is lower than normal blood pH= 7.35-7.45, so, it’s a case of acidosis. As the acidosis is due to pCO2 = 80 mm of Hg that is higher than normal pCO2 = 35-45 mm of Hg, so, it’s a case of respiratory acidosis rather than metabolic acidosis which occurs due to decreased HCO3- ions.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: This condition is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to a primary reduction in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not associated with elevated pCO2 levels, which are seen in respiratory acidosis.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary increase in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not consistent with the low pH and high pCO2 levels seen in the patient.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary decrease in pCO2 levels, often caused by hyperventilation. It is the opposite of the patient's condition, which shows low pH and high pCO2 levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Respiratory acidosis is indicated by a low blood pH and elevated pCO2 levels, suggesting impaired respiratory function and CO2 retention as the primary cause of the acidosis.

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-15

questions.text: What percentage of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 68%

 

Approximately 68% of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve.

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD à Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD à Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD à Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Approximately 68% of the data in a normal distribution lies within one standard deviation (±1σ) from the mean.

questions.text: Patient presents with urinary complaints with sterile pyuria on urine-analysis. A cystoscopy shows dilated ureteric orifice. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golf hole ureteric orifice

 

The clinical scenario describes a patient with urinary complaints and sterile pyuria, a condition where white blood cells are present in the urine without bacterial infection. The cystoscopy reveals a dilated ureteric orifice, which is characteristic of a golf hole ureteric orifice. This condition can occur due to functional obstruction or vesicoureteral reflux, where the ureteric orifice becomes dilated and appears abnormal on cystoscopy.

 

The key diagnostic clue here is the sterile pyuria combined with the specific appearance of the ureteric orifice on cystoscopy, pointing directly to a golf hole ureteric orifice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bladder diverticuli: Bladder diverticuli are pouches that form on the bladder wall and would appear as sac-like outpouchings rather than a dilated ureteric orifice. They are not typically associated with sterile pyuria.

 

Option C. Bladder ulcer: Bladder ulcers are characterized by mucosal erosions within the bladder and do not present with a dilated ureteric orifice. They may cause hematuria and pain rather than sterile pyuria.

 

Option D. Cystitis: Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, often due to infection. It typically presents with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. In cystitis, cystoscopy would show diffuse bladder wall inflammation rather than a dilated ureteric orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dilated ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy in a patient with sterile pyuria is indicative of a golf hole ureteric orifice, a condition where the orifice is abnormally dilated, often due to reflux or functional obstruction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CS sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci.

 

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili.

 

From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteraemia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.

 

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and haemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in immunocompromised hosts and those with chronic wounds but not typically presenting with purpuric rash and meningitis.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia: A common cause of bacterial meningitis but gram-positive and usually does not present with a purpuric rash.

 

Option D. E.coli: While it can cause meningitis in newborns and the elderly, it is not commonly associated with purpuric rash and gram-negative diplococci presentation in young adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a critical pathogen to consider in young adults presenting with symptoms of high-grade fever and a purpuric rash, especially when gram-negative diplococci are identified in the CSF. Rapid diagnosis and immediate treatment with appropriate antibiotics are crucial to prevent serious complications and mortality. This highlights the importance of vigilance for meningococcal disease in acute care settings.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

  • Clinical scenario suggests cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Features include early involvement of lateral rectus palsy due to involvement of abducent nerve passing through the cavernous sinus.
  • Later involvement of oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, related to the lateral wall of cavernous sinus.

*image added

 

 

  • Other signs include proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Retinoblastoma: Occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

 

Option B. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

  • Intense vaginal itching and foul-smelling greenish discharge are suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.
  • Strawberry like appearance of the cervix helps in establishing the diagnosis.
  • On vaginal smear, flagellated organism (T. vaginalis is seen)

 

Other Options:

 

Best understood by this table given below

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling, frothy yellowish-green discharge and a strawberry-like appearance of the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: What is the best contrast agent for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Iohexol

 

Barium contrast is contraindicated in esophageal perforation as it causes mediastinitis.

 

Iodinated contrast is safe for suspected GI perforation or trachea-esophageal fistula where barium is contraindicated. Iohexol (low osmolar) is preferred over Gastrograffin (high-osmolar) as it has a high chance of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrograffin: While also iodine-based and water-soluble, Gastrograffin is a high-osmolar contrast agent that can be riskier in cases of perforation due to the potential for causing severe pulmonary complications if aspirated.

 

Option C. Gadolinium: Gadolinium is primarily used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and is not suitable for gastrointestinal tract imaging, especially in the context of suspected perforations.

 

Option D. Barium sulphate: Although providing high-quality imaging, barium sulphate is contraindicated in cases of suspected perforations due to its potential to cause severe inflammatory reactions if it escapes into the mediastinal or pleural spaces.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The x-ray shows a fracture that has been treated with plating. This suggests the fracture is undergoing primary healing, which occurs when there is rigid fixation (such as with plates). In primary healing, no callus formation is seen because the bone edges are closely approximated and there is minimal micromotion. Healing occurs through direct bone formation, and intramembranous ossification can be part of this process. However, the overall mechanism here is primary healing, which is specifically associated with rigid internal fixation like plating.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creeping substitution: This refers to a bone graft healing mechanism where old bone is replaced by new bone. It does not apply to fracture healing in the context of this case.

 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: While intramembranous ossification can be involved in primary bone healing, it is not the comprehensive mechanism. The broader term is primary healing, which includes processes like intramembranous ossification but is driven by rigid fixation.

 

Option D. Secondary healing: This involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion at the fracture site, as seen with casting or nailing. This is not applicable in this case, where rigid fixation (plating) is used, leading to primary healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. He develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

  • Deficiency of GALT is the primary cause of classic galactosemia, which results in the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the body and leads to the symptoms described.

 

Classical Galactosemia:

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive in born error of metabolism due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

 

 

  • Due to the block in this enzyme, galactose-1- phosphate will accumulate in liver. This will inhibit galactokinase as well as glycogen phosphorylase. Hypoglycemia is the result.
  • Bilirubin uptake is less and bilirubin conjugation is reduced; so unconjugated bilirubin level is increased in blood.
  • There is enlargement of liver, jaundice and severe mental retardation.
  • Free galactose accumulates, leading to galactosemia. It is partly excreted in urine (galactosuria).
  • Galactose is reduced to dulcitol. The accumulation of dulcitol in the lens results in cataract due to its osmotic effect. This is called congenital cataract and is a very characteristic feature of galactosemia.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate may get deposited in renal tubules, producing tubular damage leading to generalized amino aciduria.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical manifestation including congenital cataract and presence of galactose in urine (positive benedicts test) as well as elevated blood galactose levels will help in the diagnosis.
    • Collection of fetal cells by amniocentesis may be useful in prenatal diagnosis. Heterozygous parents could be detected by elevated galactose level in blood after a galactose load.
  • Treatment: 
    • If lactose is withdrawn from the diet, most of the symptoms recede. But mental retardation, when established, will not improve. Hence early detection is most important. For affected infant lactose-free diet is given. Such special diets may be withdrawn after 4 years, when galactose-1-phosphate pyro phosphorylase becomes active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase is not directly related to galactose metabolism and is not the cause of galactosemia.

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type II Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose and galactitol in the blood and tissues. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Option D. UDP galactose-4-epimerase: UDP galactose-4-epimerase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type III Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose-1-phosphate and UDP-galactose. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency, or classic galactosemia, is a severe metabolic disorder marked by an inability to metabolize galactose properly, leading to serious systemic symptoms including jaundice, hypoglycemia, and liver dysfunction. Early diagnosis and management through dietary adjustments are crucial for preventing long-term complications.

questions.text: A lesion involving Brodmann area 22 is most likely to result in which of the following deficits? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Receptive aphasia

 

Broadmann’s area 22 corresponds to Wernicke’s area, which is primarily involved in language comprehension. A lesion in this area leads to receptive aphasia, also known as sensory or Wernicke’s aphasia. In receptive aphasia, patients have difficulty understanding spoken language, and their speech may be fluent but lacks meaning or coherence. They can produce words but often speak in nonsensical phrases or sentences that are difficult to understand, indicating a disruption in the processing of language comprehension.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Poor repetition of language: This is associated with conduction aphasia, which occurs due to a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus that connects Broca's and Wernicke's areas. It is characterized by an inability to repeat words or phrases accurately.

 

Option C. Expressive aphasia: This is also known as Broca’s aphasia, resulting from a lesion in Broadmann’s areas 44 and 45. Patients with expressive aphasia have difficulty producing speech, characterized by slow, halting, and effortful speech, but their comprehension remains intact.

 

Option D. Poor naming: Poor naming is typically observed in anomic aphasia, which occurs when the connection between language processing centers is disrupted, but it is not specific to a lesion in Broadmann’s area 22.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in Broadmann’s area 22, known as Wernicke’s area, leads to receptive aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

Explanation

 

This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.

 

Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.

 

Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucicarmine

 

Mucicarmine staining is specifically used to identify Cryptococcus, particularly useful in highlighting the thick polysaccharide capsule that is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, a yeast-like fungus that can cause serious infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The mucicarmine stain binds to the acidic polysaccharides of the fungal capsule and stains it a bright red, making it distinctly visible against a light blue background. This staining technique is especially valuable in histopathological diagnosis of cryptococcal infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giemsa stain: Primarily used for blood parasites and certain bacteria, it's not specific for fungal structures.

 

Option B. Ziehl-Nielsen stain: Used to identify acid-fast bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not fungi.

 

Option C. Gram staining: While it can stain a variety of bacteria, it is generally not effective for encapsulated fungi like Cryptococcus due to its poor affinity for fungal polysaccharide capsules.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is preferred in anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar Nerve

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting.
  • By stimulating this nerve, we can observe the twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle in the hand, which is representative of deeper muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.
  • The ulnar nerve is easily accessible and provides consistent responses.

 

Why it's preferred:

 

  • Neuromuscular monitoring aims to ensure that patients have adequate muscle paralysis during surgery and complete recovery from paralysis before waking up.
  • The ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle combination has a similar sensitivity to neuromuscular blocking drugs as the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles, which are critical for breathing and airway protection.
  • Using a Train of Four monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator, the ulnar nerve is stimulated to observe the twitch response, allowing anesthesiologists to gauge the depth of neuromuscular blockade and adjust drug dosages accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve is less commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring because it does not provide as consistent or reliable a response as the ulnar nerve. The muscle response to stimulation of the median nerve may not accurately reflect the status of deeper muscles.

 

Option C. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve innervates muscles that primarily affect the extension of the wrist and fingers. While it can be used for monitoring, it is not the preferred choice because it is less sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents compared to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Mandibular Nerve: The mandibular nerve is not used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting. It is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and does not provide a useful twitch response for assessing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in anesthesia due to its accessibility and reliable twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle, which reflects the status of critical muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 834

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tricuspid stenosis

 

The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) are key indicators for diagnosing tricuspid stenosis.

 

Tricuspid Stenosis causes an obstruction to right ventricular inflow, which leads to an increase in right atrial pressure, reflected as a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP. The mid-diastolic murmur is due to the turbulent flow across the narrowed tricuspid valve during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Stenosis: While it can cause a diastolic murmur, it typically does not cause a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP unless there is secondary pulmonary hypertension affecting the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Mitral Regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur and, if severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension, may indirectly cause changes in the JVP, but it does not directly cause a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Option D. Tricuspid Regurgitation: This condition causes a large 'v' wave in the JVP due to backflow of blood into the right atrium during systole, not a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent 'a' wave in JVP and a mid-diastolic murmur are indicative of tricuspid stenosis, a condition causing right ventricular inflow obstruction.

questions.text: The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome includes all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Mental Retardation

 

Explanation: 

 

The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) consists of cataract, deafness, and congenital heart defects (particularly Patent Ductus Arteriosus). This triad represents the most characteristic manifestations of maternal rubella infection during pregnancy, especially when infection occurs during the first trimester. While mental retardation can occur in children with CRS, it is not part of the classical diagnostic triad but rather an additional manifestation that may be present in severe cases.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cataract - Correct component of the CRS triad. Cataracts are typically bilateral but can be unilateral and develop from damage to the developing lens during embryogenesis.

 

Option B. Deafness - Correct component of the CRS triad. Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common manifestation of CRS, affecting up to 80% of infected infants.

 

Option C. Heart Defects - Correct component of the CRS triad. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common cardiac defect, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis and ventricular septal defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome consists of cataracts, deafness, and congenital heart defects (primarily PDA). Additional manifestations may include microcephaly, mental retardation, purpuric rash ("blueberry muffin" appearance), hepatosplenomegaly, and intrauterine growth restriction.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should she discontinue? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

 

These medications are contraindicated during pregnancy because they are associated with fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Therefore, women who are planning to conceive should discontinue these medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labetalol: Labetalol is generally safe for use during pregnancy and is a treatment option for hypertension in pregnant women. It is not necessary to discontinue this medication.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers like nifedipine are also generally considered safe during pregnancy and are often used to manage hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Option D. Alpha methyldopa: Alpha methyldopa is also considered safe during pregnancy and is commonly used for managing hypertension in this population.

 

Given the woman's intention to conceive, discontinuing Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors would be the most appropriate course of action to protect both her health and that of her future child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors should be discontinued in women who are planning to conceive due to their associated risks of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Alternative antihypertensive medications that are safer during pregnancy include labetalol, calcium channel blockers, and alpha methyldopa.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch, except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Levator veli palatini

 

Levator veli palatini: The muscle responsible for elevating the soft palate, playing an essential role in swallowing. It prevents food and liquids from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing. This muscle is not derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch but from the 4th pharyngeal arch. It is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus, with contributions primarily from the vagus nerve (CN X).

 

First pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

 

  • Muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, lateral and medial pterygoids)
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani
  • Tensor velipalatini and
  • Anterior 2/3 of tongue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial pterygoids: It is one of the muscles of mastication which assists in elevating the mandible and plays a role in the side-to-side movement of the jaw. It originates from the medial pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone and inserts into the medial surface of the mandible. The medial pterygoid is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Lateral pterygoids: Like the medial pterygoid, it is also a muscle of mastication which depresses the mandible and side-to-side jaw movements. The muscle has two heads, superior and inferior, and it inserts into the neck of the mandible and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. Derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch, it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option D. Tensor veli palatini: It is responsible for tensing the soft palate and assists in opening the auditory (Eustachian) tube, equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the nasopharynx. This muscle is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is unique among the palatal muscles because it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin. He started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 mg/dL. The plasma therapeutic range is 1 mg/dL. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long one should wait before resuming the treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 80 hours

 

To determine how long it will take for the patient's serum digoxin concentration to decrease to a therapeutic level (1 mg/dL) from 4 mg/dL, we need to consider the drug's half-life. The half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, which means that every 40 hours, the concentration of the drug in the plasma will be reduced by half.

 

  • Initial concentration: 4 mg/dL
  • Therapeutic concentration: 1 mg/dL
  • Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours

 

We can use the concept of half-lives to calculate the time needed:

 

  1. After the first half-life (40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 4 mg/dL to 2 mg/dL.
  2. After the second half-life (another 40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 2 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL.

 

Therefore, it will take 80 hours for the digoxin concentration to fall from 4 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL, which is within the therapeutic range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient experiencing side effects from digoxin with a serum concentration of 4 mg/dL, wait 80 hours (two half-lives) for the concentration to decrease to the therapeutic range before resuming treatment.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are:

 

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

 

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon primarily works to increase blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not play a significant role in shifting potassium intracellularly.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It is not involved in potassium homeostasis or its intracellular movement.

 

Option D. Lactic acid: Lactic acid does not facilitate the intracellular movement of potassium. In fact, metabolic acidosis (which can be associated with elevated lactic acid levels) tends to cause potassium to move out of cells into the extracellular space, exacerbating hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 agonists, such as Epinephrine, are effective in promoting the intracellular movement of potassium, thereby reducing serum potassium levels in cases of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

choices.text: Lyophylised Amphotericin B

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Voriconazole

 

Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium.

 

The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: While effective against Aspergillus species, itraconazole is generally considered less effective than voriconazole for invasive cases due to its variable bioavailability and slower onset of action.

 

Option C. Lyophylised Amphotericin B: Often used as a second-line treatment or in patients who cannot tolerate azole antifungals. It has a broader spectrum but is also associated with more severe side effects, particularly nephrotoxicity.

 

Option D. Posaconazole: This is another alternative, especially for prophylaxis against Aspergillus in high-risk patients, but it is generally used when voriconazole is contraindicated or not tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Voriconazole's effectiveness, broad spectrum of activity, and favorable pharmacokinetic profile make it the first-line treatment for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, offering significant benefits in terms of efficacy and patient outcomes in severe fungal infections.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The Jacobson nerve / tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Jacobson nerve = tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal (IX cranial nerve) – supplies middle ear mucosa. Referred otalgia from tonsillitis / pharyngitis / Cancers of base of tongue is due to this nerve common innervation (ear & pharynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Greater Auricular Nerve: Arises from the cervical plexus (C2, C3) and primarily innervates the skin over the parotid gland and mastoid region, not typically involved in referred ear pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), which innervates the anterior auricle and external acoustic meatus, contributing to sensations in these areas but not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option D. Auricular Branch of Vagus Nerve: Also known as Arnold’s nerve, supplies the concha and part of the external auditory canal and could potentially contribute to referred otalgia, but not primarily responsible in cases of tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:
